review.title: Toward a Robust Diversity-Based Model to Detect Changes of Context
review.abstract: Being able to automatically and quickly understand the user context during a session is a main issue for recommender systems. As a first step toward achieving that goal, we propose a model that observes in real time the diversity brought by each item relatively to a short sequence of consultations, corresponding to the recent user history. Our model has a complexity in constant time, and is generic since it can apply to any type of items within an online service (e.g. profiles, products, music tracks) and any application domain (e-commerce, social network, music streaming), as long as we have partial item descriptions. The observation of the diversity level over time allows us to detect implicit changes. In the long term, we plan to characterize the context, i.e. to find common features among a contiguous sub-sequence of items between two changes of context determined by our model. This will allow us to make context-aware and privacy-preserving recommendations, to explain them to users. As this is an ongoing research, the first step consists here in studying the robustness of our model while detecting changes of context. In order to do so, we use a music corpus of 100 users and more than 210,000 consultations (number of songs played in the global history). We validate the relevancy of our detections by finding connections between changes of context and events, such as ends of session. Of course, these events are a subset of the possible changes of context, since there might be several contexts within a session. We altered the quality of our corpus in several manners, so as to test the performances of our model when confronted with sparsity and different types of items. The results show that our model is robust and constitutes a promising approach.

sections.heading: A. Diversity in Recommender Systems
sections.text: This dimension is considered in the literature in two ways: some analyze the impact of diversity on user behavior, while others integrate diversity within a set of items. Thus, the diversification of recommendations consists in identifying the best items that are very similar to the known preferences of users, while reducing the similarity between these recommendations. A diversity classification was proposed by Adomavicius and Kwon [1], which distinguishes individual diversity and aggregate diversity depending on whether we are interested in making recommendations to individuals or groups of users.

sections.heading: B. Context-Aware Recommender Systems
sections.text: Integrating context into the referral process is an increasing field of research known as CARS, acronym for Context Aware Recommender Systems. In their state-of-the-art, Adomavicius et al. present several approaches such as contextual modeling, pre / post-filter method for using contextual factors to adapt recommendations to the context of users [2]. Contextual factors are all information that can be collected and used by a system to determine and characterize the current context of the user. For example, a system can use the location of the user to adapt the recommendation [13]. The main drawbacks of this type of systems are that they are invasive, using personal information and most often require a complex representation model. For example, such systems can use ontologies to determine the user context [7]. However, such an ontology cannot be transferred from one domain to another.

sections.heading: A. Material
sections.text: To test our various hypotheses, we decided to do our evaluation based on a set of music data. This choice was made because music files have many advantages. Firstly, music files have their own consultation time, i.e. the time spent consulting a song cannot vary from one user to another. Secondly, song metadata can be easily accessed by using some specialized services such as Echnonest1 or Musicbrainz2. Finally, users often listen to several songs in a row, as opposed to a film corpus, for example. Our data set contains 212,233 tracks listened to by 100 users. We obtained these consultations by using the Last.fm3 API to collect listening events from June 28, 2005 to December 18, 2014. Our data set consists of 41,742 individual records performed by 5,370 individual artists. To create the sessions for all users, we assumed that a session is a sequence of metadata larger than the 15 minutes.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: Our model allows to monitor the natural diversity that is contained in the user's navigation path over time and, although part of an ongoing research, already presents many strengths to characterize the context of the user. First, it has a complexity in constant time, since at each step of the time we only accept computational diversity on a fixed and small scale of history. This makes our model highly scalable. Furthermore, it preserves privacy since it does not require personal information about the active user (even if it allows the use of information that other users accept) and allows us to forget the navigation path beyond recent history. Finally, it is awesome because our equations correspond to any kind of attributes and do not require ontology to put words into context. One of the issues addressed in this paper was our ability to predict changes in the implicit context without knowing what will happen next.
